alert.note: Alert for Swain (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 09 at 2:44PM EST until January 10 at 10:00PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg SC has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in North Carolina... Tuckasegee River At Bryson City affecting Swain County. .Heavy rain has ended across Swain County and the lower Tuckasegee River watershed. Storm-total rainfall of 3-5 inches occurred, causing significant rises on both the Oconaluftee and Tuckasegee Rivers from Cherokee to Birdtown to Bryson City. This will cause nuisance to Minor flooding along the lower Oconaluftee and Tuckasgee rivers, with impacts to low-lying elevations near Bryson City including Bear Hunter Campground, Island Park, and Old River Rd. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TOMORROW EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Tuckasegee River at Bryson City. * WHEN...Until late tomorrow evening. * IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, The river will overflow its banks in Island Park and low-lying areas along Island and Collins Streets will begin to flood. During heavy rainfall, Toot Hollow Branch that flows into the river will likely overflow its banks and flood areas along the branch especially along Waters Street. Bear Hunter Campground will experience more significant flooding. At 12.0 feet, The lowest elevations of businesses and property near Everett Street and along Island and Carringer Streets may begin to flood. In Whittier, businesses along the river may have water in their loading docks. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:15 PM EST Tuesday the stage was 9.6 feet and rising rapidly - Action/Advisory Stage is 9.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above Minor Flood Stage by 4pm this afternoon to a crest of 12.0 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below Minor Flood Stage early tomorrow afternoon. - Minor Flood Stage is 10.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp The next statement will be issued beforeWednesday evening at 1000 PM EST.
